text: Also curious about indicators... I've always developed my own but often wonder if there are ANY financial indicators that are useful in sports betting? At first glance, it would seem that betfair markets are similar to Forex/Stock markets, but with a much shorter lifespan.

elements.text: Also curious about indicators... I've always developed my own but often wonder if there are ANY financial indicators that are useful in sports betting? At first glance, it would seem that betfair markets are similar to Forex/Stock markets, but with a much shorter lifespan.

text: Not really, they are simpler,  you have discrete prices and you have bounded losses and wins

elements.text: Not really, they are simpler,  you have discrete prices and you have bounded losses and wins

text: Indexes that appear in finance spend a lot of their effort to understand what's the delta between the current evaluation and a baseline evaluation to generate the market 'sentiment'. You don't need all that crap, because the market is transparently telling you this via the odds.

elements.text: Indexes that appear in finance spend a lot of their effort to understand what's the delta between the current evaluation and a baseline evaluation to generate the market 'sentiment'. You don't need all that crap, because the market is transparently telling you this via the odds.

text: (Plus you have non-binary markets, but I guess that's just a peculiarity)

elements.text: (Plus you have non-binary markets, but I guess that's just a peculiarity)

text:
• The equation gives the probability that horse i wins race j
• The exp(beta * x_i^j) terms can be thought of as the horse's strength or ability
• The fraction is just converting the strengths into probabilities; a horse's chance of winning is their strength divided by the sum of strengths of all horses
• Now to break down exp(beta * x_i^j). exp() is just the exponential function
• beta and x_i^j are vectors. The beta are the weights for the different variables and the x_i^j are the values of those variables
• The vector multiplication is just a short hand for saying weight1 * value1 + weight2 * value2 + ...
• So your first variable might be a binary variable whether the horse won its previous race and your regression may have fit the parameter for this as 0.5 then for a horse that won their previous race you have 0.5 * 1 + weight2 * value2 + ... and for a horse that didn't win their previous race you have 0.5 * 0 + weight2 * value2 + ...

elements.text: The equation gives the probability that horse i wins race j
The exp(beta * x_i^j) terms can be thought of as the horse's strength or ability
The fraction is just converting the strengths into probabilities; a horse's chance of winning is their strength divided by the sum of strengths of all horses
Now to break down exp(beta * x_i^j). exp() is just the exponential function
beta and x_i^j are vectors. The beta are the weights for the different variables and the x_i^j are the values of those variables
The vector multiplication is just a short hand for saying weight1 * value1 + weight2 * value2 + ...

So your first variable might be a binary variable whether the horse won its previous race and your regression may have fit the parameter for this as 0.5 then for a horse that won their previous race you have 0.5 * 1 + weight2 * value2 + ... and for a horse that didn't win their previous race you have 0.5 * 0 + weight2 * value2 + ...

text: These are in general linear models where you use a linear combination of variables to generate a probability. So, yes, it normalizes things. It does it in a specific way though, Assume you only have 2 horses just for plotting reasons, it will look like this: <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sigmoid_function#/media/File:Logistic-curve.svg>

attachments.title: Sigmoid function
attachments.text:
A sigmoid function is a mathematical function having a characteristic "S"-shaped curve or sigmoid curve.  A common example of a sigmoid function is the logistic function shown in the first figure and defined by the formula:

  
    
      
        S
        (
        x
        )
        =
        
          
            1
            
              1
              +
              
                e
                
                  −
                  x
                
              
            
          
        
        =
        
          
            
              e
              
                x
              
            
            
              
                e
                
                  x
                
              
              +
              1
            
          
        
        .
      
    
    {\displaystyle S(x)={\frac {1}{1+e^{-x}}}={\frac {e^{x}}{e^{x}+1}}.}
  Other standard sigmoid functions are given in the Examples section.
Special cases of the sigmoid function include the Gompertz curve (used in modeling systems that saturate at large values of x) and the ogee curve (used in the spillway of some dams). Sigmoid functions have domain of all real numbers, with return (response) value commonly monotonically increasing but could be decreasing. Sigmoid functions most often show a return value (y axis) in the range 0 to 1. Another commonly used range is from −1 to 1.
A wide variety of sigmoid functions including the logistic and hyperbolic tangent functions have been used as the activation function of artificial neurons. Sigmoid curves are also common in statistics as cumulative distribution functions (which go from 0 to 1), such as the integrals of the logistic density, the normal density, and Student's t probability density functions.  The logistic sigmoid function is invertible, and its inverse is the logit function.

elements.text: These are in general linear models where you use a linear combination of variables to generate a probability. So, yes, it normalizes things. It does it in a specific way though, Assume you only have 2 horses just for plotting reasons, it will look like this:

text: If you look at the graph, it goes from 0 to 1 so it looks like. a probability. Moreover, in the center of the graph it is almost a line (linear) and then the values saturate

elements.text: If you look at the graph, it goes from 0 to 1 so it looks like. a probability. Moreover, in the center of the graph it is almost a line (linear) and then the values saturate

text: The weights distribution changes the shape of this, i.e. how fast it saturates to 1 or 0 and where the center of the curve is (it could be at value 3 instead of 0 for example)

elements.text: The weights distribution changes the shape of this, i.e. how fast it saturates to 1 or 0 and where the center of the curve is (it could be at value 3 instead of 0 for example)

text: The key point of these things is that they are linear models, i.e. you give one weight for each of the values you put inside, and you don't spend time thinking about things that are intercorrelated. It's very simple, but that's a very good place to start when thinking about probabilities that are function of multiple variables.

elements.text: The key point of these things is that they are linear models, i.e. you give one weight for each of the values you put inside, and you don't spend time thinking about things that are intercorrelated. It's very simple, but that's a very good place to start when thinking about probabilities that are function of multiple variables.

text:
<@U01HQ97J5HA> I think we are of a "certain" age where probability and statistics _wasn't_ part of the standard curriculum. Plus I took the direction of an engineering apprenticeship, where the maths of calculating the bend elasticity of steel or the voltage drop on 25M of cable is an exact science. Calculating the probability of arriving at work on time, given that we'd had 9 pints of scrumpy the night before, was about as near as we ever got to statistics.:grinning:

I'd also like to be able to understand those sort of equations as I normally stop reading once the first one appears...my thought process being that if I don't understand the equation, then I won't interpret the rest of the literature correctly. Some simple practical examples would also be useful.

I'd also like to be able to understand those sort of equations as I normally stop reading once the first one appears...my thought process being that if I don't understand the equation, then I won't interpret the rest of the literature correctly. Some simple practical examples would also be useful.
